author: By Steven Lee Myers and Jason Gutierrez
title: With Swarms of Ships, Beijing Tightens Its Grip on South China Sea
description: After building artificial islands, China is using large fleets of ostensibly civilian boats to press other countries’ vessels out of disputed waters.
content: The Chinese ships settled in like unwanted guests who wouldn’t leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wehner
title: Why Is Jesus Still Wounded After His Resurrection?
description: “The risen but scarred body of Christ is the ultimate signifier of divine empathy.”
content: As a person of the Christian faith, I’ve long understood what the Apostle Peter meant when he said, “By his wounds you have been healed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Guggenheim, Lauryn Higgins and Mike Ives
title: More than 3 million people are now receiving a Covid vaccine in the U.S. each day.
description: The milestone, which comes amid a worrying resurgence of variants in certain parts of the country, reflects a steady increase in the capacity of states to deliver shots into arms.
content: For the first time, more than three million people, on average, are receiving a Covid-19 vaccine each day in the United States, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. And on Saturday, the country reported over four million doses in a single day for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Georgia’s Election Law, and Why Turnout Isn’t Easy to Turn Off
description: Making voting convenient doesn’t necessarily translate into more votes, research shows.
content: There’s nothing unusual about exaggeration in politics. But when it comes to the debate over voting rights, something more than exaggeration is going on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: Fred Piscop drives a massive herd of difficult words our way.
content: SPLIT DECISIONS — This is the first time since solving this variety of puzzle that I felt, for a moment, as though I was building up some momentum and “got” a solving method that worked — I fairly flew through the east side of this grid today by making myself guess some of the longer entries, rather than instinctively sticking to short words. This tactic worked for a while but blew up on me, so next time I’ll try something different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Maria Cramer
title: The Latest Issue in Divorces: Who Gets the Embryos?
description: Amid the pandemic, I.V.F. rates are on the rise, and so are disputes about what to do with remaining frozen embryos when couples split up. For some, it has gotten messy.
content: When Peter Goldin, a 44-year-old communications director, and his husband decided to start a family through in vitro fertilization, they faced mounds of paperwork at the fertility clinic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Hunter Biden, Matt Gaetz and Nonstop Depravity
description: In a memoir of his vices, Hunter Biden sends a love letter to his brother.
content: WASHINGTON — A Twitter wag summed it up best: “Matt Gaetz is everything the Republicans were looking for in Hunter Biden.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Reopened. For 36 Minutes. It’s a Start.
description: Before a masked, distanced and virus-tested audience of 150, the dancer Savion Glover and the actor Nathan Lane performed, celebrating theater and testing safety protocols a year after the pandemic caused theaters to close.
content: Three hundred and eighty-seven days after Broadway went dark, a faint light started to glimmer on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: How Brexit Ruined Easter for Britain’s Chocolate Makers
description: Exports of chocolate to Europe have turned into a nightmare of paperwork and delays, making fine British chocolate scarce in Europe.
content: LONDON — For the second year in a row, Easter will be a largely online affair, with socially distanced egg hunts and virtual church services. But there will be one notable difference here in the Britain. Domestic chocolate makers, who should be celebrating one of their busiest times of year, are fuming instead, and all of them cite the same cause: Brexit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: ‘Like a Miracle’: Israel’s Vaccine Success Allows Easter Crowds in Jerusalem
description: Last year, the pandemic forced the cancellation of the Good Friday procession in Jerusalem. This Holy Week, local Christians are thronging the streets of the Old City.
content: JERUSALEM — On Friday morning, in the Old City of Jerusalem, in the limestone alleys of the Christian quarter, it was as if the pandemic had never happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: ‘I Was Failing’: Bystanders Carry Guilt From Watching George Floyd Die
description: Their pain has been mostly hidden for the last 10 months. But over the first week of Derek Chauvin’s murder trial, it spilled tearfully into the open as witnesses testified to their shared trauma.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Alyssa Funari needed a cord to connect her cellphone to the car to play music, so she pulled up to a corner store in South Minneapolis one early evening last May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tsubasa Kajitani Wins Augusta National Women’s Amateur in Playoff
description: The 17-year-old from Japan started the day slow on the tough course at Augusta National but rallied for a surprise sudden-death finish.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The first Augusta National Women’s Amateur in 2019 featured a closing charge by the eventual winner, Jennifer Kupcho, who faced down the intimidating back nine by playing her final six holes in five under par.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: We Have All Hit a Wall
description: Confronting late-stage pandemic burnout, with everything from edibles to Exodus.
content: Like many of us, the writer Susan Orlean is having a hard time concentrating these days. “Good morning to everyone,” she tweeted recently, “but especially to the sentence I just rewrote for the tenth time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: Argentina’s President Tests Positive for Coronavirus Despite Vaccination
description: Alberto Fernández, who received early results on his 62nd birthday, was confirmed to have the virus in a later P.C.R. test. His symptoms were said to be mild.
content: BUENOS AIRES — President Alberto Fernández of Argentina tested positive for Covid-19 on Saturday and was experiencing mild symptoms despite having been vaccinated earlier this year, becoming the latest in a series of world leaders who have contracted the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: In Turkey’s Failed Coup, Trainees Face the Same Stiff Punishments as Generals
description: The families of trainee pilots sentenced to life in prison broke their silence to protest the men’s innocence. The pilots are among more than 600 trainees and conscripts swept up in prosecutions.
content: ISTANBUL — Their happiness shines out of the photograph: 14 graduates of Turkey’s Air Force Academy celebrating their completion of a flight training program with a picture together in front of a fighter jet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar
title: 22 Mummies Are Moved in a Glittering Display in Cairo
description: But the made-for-TV spectacle also underlined the jarring divide between Egypt’s celebrated past and its uncertain present.
content: CAIRO — Downtown Cairo came to a near standstill Saturday night as 22 mummies were moved from a museum where they had resided for more than a century to a new home, transported atop custom-made vehicles in a glittering, meticulously planned procession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Here’s What Readers Told Us About Feeling Burned Out
description: At this point in the pandemic, it feels that we have, all, collectively, hit a wall. Last week, The New York Times asked readers to tell us about work burnout they’re experiencing — nearly 700 people responded in two days. The responses were funny, vulnerable and indicative of a universal sense of: “We’ve had enough.” The collective picture they painted was of a work force struggling to do tasks that were once easy, people who know they are lucky to have a job but dream of quitting, and who would do anything to never have a Zoom meeting again.
content: At this point in the pandemic, it feels that we have, all, collectively, hit a wall. Last week, The New York Times asked readers to tell us about work burnout they’re experiencing — nearly 700 people responded in two days. The responses were funny, vulnerable and indicative of a universal sense of: “We’ve had enough.” The collective picture they painted was of a work force struggling to do tasks that were once easy, people who know they are lucky to have a job but dream of quitting, and who would do anything to never have a Zoom meeting again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: What to Watch For in the Men’s Final Four
description: After a battle of Texans, Gonzaga will seek further perfection against a U.C.L.A. team that has mastered the art of survival.
content: [Follow live updates from the men’s Final Four on Saturday.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel and Ken Belson
title: Houston Police Announce Investigation Into a Complaint About Deshaun Watson
description: The police did not clarify whether the complaint had come from any of the 21 women who have filed lawsuits accusing him of assault and sexual misconduct.
content: The Houston Police Department said on Friday that it had begun an investigation concerning Deshaun Watson, the star quarterback for the Houston Texans, after a complaint was filed against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rana F. Sweis
title: Women, 86 Percent Absent From Jordan’s Work Force, Are Left Behind
description: “As long as women are absent from the labor market, they are absent from the public sphere,” one advocate said.
content: AMMAN, Jordan — Marwa Alomari’s compassionate and patient style made her a popular English teacher, filling her classes in Irbid, Jordan, with eager students and her off hours with private tutoring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Thousands Protest Against Policing Bill in Britain, With Clashes in London
description: Protesters have rallied across cities in England and Wales to denounce new legislation that would give the police more powers to dislodge demonstrators at gatherings.
content: LONDON — Thousands of people protested Saturday in several cities across England and Wales against a sweeping crime and policing bill, with some in London clashing with the police in scenes that may further fuel a raging national debate over law enforcement tactics in Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: The Virus Drove Churchgoers Away. Will Easter Bring Them Back?
description: Churches across New York are hoping increased attendance for Holy Week services will help bring back lost donations that have led to financial hardship during the pandemic.
content: The Rev. Henry Torres told his parishioners, who had gathered on Palm Sunday in socially distanced rows of half-empty pews, that God had not abandoned them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: One Republican’s Lonely Fight Against a Flood of Disinformation
description: After losing an ugly congressional race last year, Denver Riggleman is leading a charge against the conspiracy-mongering coursing through his party. He doesn’t have many allies.
content: AFTON, Va. — Denver Riggleman stood virtually alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Baylor Overwhelms Houston to Reach N.C.A.A. Tournament Final
description: “Could I believe it three years ago?” Jared Butler said before leading the Bears to a rout. “No.”
content: INDIANAPOLIS — When Jared Butler left Alabama in the summer of 2018, enrolling at Baylor just before his freshman year started, he walked into what was a middling program, one that had not reached the N.C.A.A. tournament the prior season and had been known for its early flameouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rana F. Sweis, Isabel Kershner and Nicholas Kulish
title: Jordan Arrests High-Profile Figures, and Ex-Crown Prince Cries Foul
description: Those arrested included a member of the royal family and  a longtime confidant of King Abdullah II. In a dramatic video, the country’s former crown prince says he has been silenced.
content: AMMAN, Jordan — The Jordanian government has arrested high-profile figures in the kingdom, including a member of the royal family and a former chief of the royal court, with officials citing “the security and stability of Jordan” as intrigue consumed the country Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: The Key to Successful Pandemic Parenting? Take Care of Yourself, Too.
description: The actor Lance Gross and the stylist Rebecca Gross learned to balance family life and careers by taking time for themselves.
content: Last November, Lance Gross, an actor known for his roles on various Tyler Perry productions including “Tyler Perry’s House of Payne,” had to say goodbye to his family for four weeks as he embarked on his first movie project since the coronavirus lockdown began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Nicholas Fandos and Ben Decker
title: Driver Rams Into Officers at Capitol, Killing One and Injuring Another
description: The attack shocked a Capitol slowly returning to normalcy after the Jan. 6 riot, raising new questions about securing the complex.
content: WASHINGTON — The band of razor wire-topped fencing around the Capitol had recently come down. The heavy National Guard presence had begun to thin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Help! My Apartment Building Is a Movie Set
description: You can’t stop your landlord from renting out common areas to a film crew, but you can try to get some concessions from the production.
content: Q: Tenants at my New Paltz, N.Y., rental building were recently informed by our landlord that a production crew would be filming scenes for a major motion-picture on the property for four days later this month. No one asked us, yet we are being asked for our “understanding” and “cooperation,” which includes moving our vehicles from assigned parking spaces. During the busiest day, 70 people will be on site from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m., a violation of the local noise ordinance. Inconvenience aside, it sounds like a potential health hazard during the pandemic. Is this legal? What can be done?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: In Moving All-Star Game, Another Sport Flexes Its Activist Muscles
description: Pulled by public opinion and sometimes their own players, leagues and teams are wading in to issues around race and social activism as never before.
content: For major American sports leagues that long have taken pains to stay out of divisive issues around race and social activism, the past few years have seen a remarkable awakening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How Lower-Income Americans Get Cheated on Property Taxes
description: Many homeowners are paying a total of billions of dollars extra because of inequities in assessing property values.
content: Americans expect to pay property taxes at the same rates as their neighbors. But across most of the United States, flat-rate property taxation is a sham.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Aishvarya Kavi
title: Capitol Suspect Struggled Before Attack, but Motive Remains Unclear
description: Noah R. Green had been distressed but had no known history of violence when he rammed his car into two police officers, killing one and injuring another before being killed himself.
content: On the football field at Christopher Newport University in Virginia, Noah R. Green was No. 21, a dependable and good-natured, if soft-spoken, presence in the defensive backfield. Off the field, he was laser-focused on Black economic empowerment, counseling teammates on financial management and plotting a career helping close the racial wealth gap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Arizona Shocks UConn and Storms to the N.C.A.A. Title Game
description: The Wildcats dominated the top-seeded Huskies and advanced to their first appearance in the women’s final. They will meet Stanford on Sunday.
content: From the very first possession on Friday night, Arizona’s national semifinal game against Connecticut was an exercise in slow, grind-it-out basketball, with a lot of missed shots and long, labored possessions. It was exactly what Arizona wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Benjamin Mueller
title: Virus Variants Threaten to Draw Out the Pandemic, Scientists Say
description: Declining infection rates overall masked a rise in more contagious forms of the coronavirus. Vaccines will stop the spread, if Americans postpone celebration just a bit longer.
content: For weeks, the mood in much of the United States has been buoyant. Cases, hospitalizations and deaths from the coronavirus have fallen steeply from their highs, and millions of people are being newly vaccinated every day. Restaurants, shops and schools have reopened. Some states, like Texas and Florida, have abandoned precautions altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: Fed Up With Remote Learning, Governors Make a Push to Reopen Schools
description: A bipartisan group of governors decided to flex its muscle and get students back into classrooms, despite union resistance and bureaucratic hesitancy.
content: In Ohio, Gov. Mike DeWine offered school districts early access to vaccines for their staff if they committed to opening classrooms by March 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Fort Sill Soldiers Suspended as Army Investigates Sexual Assault Claim
description: The U.S. Army Criminal Investigation Command is investigating the allegations, which were brought forward by a female trainee late last month.
content: Soldiers at Fort Sill in Oklahoma have been suspended from their duties as Army investigators conduct an inquiry into a sexual assault allegation, military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Apprehensions at Border Reach Highest Level in at Least 15 Years
description: More migrant families are entering the United States and being released, new figures for March show, as thousands of children remain in detention facilities.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration apprehended more than 170,000 migrants at the southwest border in March, the most in any month for at least 15 years and up nearly 70 percent from February, as thousands of children remained backed up in detention facilities and border agents released an increasing number of migrant families into the United States, government documents obtained by The New York Times show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: How Do We Stop the Parade of Gun Deaths?
description: A first step: Biden should act urgently against untraceable “ghost guns.”
content: In California, a 9-year-old child was one of four people shot dead at a real estate office on Wednesday. Shortly before that, 10 people were massacred in a Colorado grocery store, and eight people were executed in Atlanta-area spas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Charms
description: Peter A. Collins woos us with a romp of a Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We had a lot of difficult weekend puzzles in March, I think, or at least a few notably difficult ones. I solve on paper and don’t keep track of speeds, but I’d estimate that I did 90 percent of this Peter Collins construction in 50 percent of the time I need with a really hard grid, but then I spent that long again trying to finish the southwest corner, so all in all the time I took to solve was a wash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: How Trump Steered Supporters Into Unwitting Donations
description: Online donors were guided into weekly recurring contributions. Demands for refunds spiked. Complaints to banks and credit card companies soared. But the money helped keep Donald Trump’s struggling campaign afloat.
content: Stacy Blatt was in hospice care last September listening to Rush Limbaugh’s dire warnings about how badly Donald J. Trump’s campaign needed money when he went online and chipped in everything he could: $500.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Her Ballot Didn’t Count. She Faces 5 Years in Prison for Casting It.
description: A Texas woman is appealing her conviction of voting illegally in the 2016 election. A lawyer says her prosecution “guts the entire purpose of the provisional ballot system.”
content: On Election Day 2016, Crystal Mason went to vote after her mother insisted that she make her voice heard in the presidential election. When her name didn’t appear on official voting rolls at her polling place in Tarrant County, Texas, she filled out a provisional ballot, not thinking anything of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: 6 Takeaways From the First Week of the Derek Chauvin Trial
description: It began with tears and shaky voices, and ended with a stunning condemnation by a senior police officer. The trial of Mr. Chauvin, charged in the death of George Floyd, will resume on Monday.
content: The first week of the murder trial of Derek Chauvin in Minneapolis was marked by emotional accounts from bystanders who watched Mr. Chauvin pin George Floyd to the ground for more than nine minutes in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Kemp Lashes M.L.B. as Republicans Defend Georgia’s Voting Law
description: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia, who is starting his re-election push, argued that the league had “caved to fear” in moving its All-Star Game as he tried to rally Republicans around the new voting limits.
content: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia on Saturday issued a blistering critique of Major League Baseball’s decision to pull its All-Star Game out of the state over the new law there restricting voting, arguing that the move would deliver an economic hit to Georgians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Paula McLain Wrote a Thriller — and This Time, It’s Personal
description: The author of “The Paris Wife” made a name for herself exploring the lives of real women. In her first suspense novel, “When the Stars Go Dark,” she faces her own demons.
content: If you talk to enough writers, you’ll notice a theme of books and words as saviors. You’ll hear how a meaningful novel landed, at just the right moment, in the hands of a person who was alone and scared; how a humble ballpoint pen became a microphone, a stage, a shield or a sword.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Is Biden Missing His Chance on Guns?
description: President Biden spent decades pushing for gun control. In the early days of his presidency, he’s taking a far less aggressive approach.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Technology After the Pandemic
description: Few investors have a broader view of the global tech landscape than Bob van Dijk. What does he see?
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: April the Giraffe, Who Became an Internet Sensation in 2017, Dies
description: April, 20, gained fame giving birth as millions watched via livestream. She was euthanized on Friday because of her worsening arthritis.
content: April the giraffe, an internet sensation who gave birth nearly four years ago as an audience of millions watched via livestream, and helped educate the public about her species, died on Friday, Animal Adventure Park, her home, announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly, Matthew Goldstein, Matt Phillips and Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: He Built a $10 Billion Investment Firm. It Fell Apart in Days.
description: Banks were eager to do business with Bill Hwang and his Archegos Capital Management — until he ran out of money.
content: Until recently, Bill Hwang sat atop one of the biggest — and perhaps least known — fortunes on Wall Street. Then his luck ran out.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Depressing’ Domino Effect: Working Class Is Struggling, and Their Colleges Are, Too
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 3, 2021.
content: “It’s impossible to learn to weld, drive a truck, cook, draw blood, wire a network online, without handling the equipment and tools.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Gary Sanchez Homers Again as Yankees Top Blue Jays
description: Sanchez’s homer and Corey Kluber’s solid first start in pinstripes helped the Yankees get their first win of the season.
content: Gary Sanchez joined Elston Howard in 1963 as the only Yankees catchers to homer in each of the first two games of the season and Jay Bruce blooped a two-run single in the seventh for his first hit with his new team in the Yankees’ 5-3 win over the Toronto Blue Jays on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Arthur Kopit, Whose ‘Oh Dad’ Shook Up the Theater, Dies at 83
description: A three-time Tony nominee, he first became known for avant-garde works, many of them christened with rambling titles, that sparked spirited reactions.
content: Arthur Kopit, the avant-garde playwright who thrust Off Broadway into a new era with the absurdist satirical farce “Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mamma’s Hung You in the Closet and I’m Feelin’ So Sad” and earned Tony Award nominations for two wildly different plays, “Indians” and “Wings,” and the musical “Nine,” died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Joy Dong
title: They Survived Taiwan’s Train Crash. Their Loved Ones Did Not.
description: A woman lost her husband and their two children, who were athletes at a university. A man held his 5-year-old daughter in his arms in the minutes before she died.
content: HUALIEN, Taiwan — Crawling through the smoky wreckage, she first found her husband and son pinned under luggage lockers and mangled steel, but they weren’t breathing. Then she called her daughter’s name. A faint voice responded: “I’m over here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Kenya, expressing concern about counterfeit vaccines, blocks private imports of doses.
description: The move comes after private health facilities started administering Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine, charging up to $70 for a shot.
content: Kenya has canceled the private importation and distribution of Covid-19 vaccines, citing the need to safeguard against the possible introduction of fake doses and to ensure “greater transparency and accountability.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Listening to Those Who Saw George Floyd Die
description: The witnesses who testified this week are still tormented by that day.
content: It has been more than 10 months since George Floyd was pinned to the Minneapolis pavement, a knee hard on his neck as the life drained senselessly out of him and he moaned, again and again, “I can’t breathe.” The small group of people who were there — along with countless others who watched the horrifying video — have had all that time to come to terms with it, or at least to try.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Forgotten Copy of Super Mario Bros. Sets Record at Auction
description: The game was bought as a Christmas gift in 1986 but was left in a desk drawer for 35 years. It sold for $660,000 at an auction on Friday.
content: An unopened copy of Nintendo’s Super Mario Bros. that had been bought in 1986 as a Christmas gift but sat forgotten in a desk drawer until recently was sold on Friday for $660,000, according to an auction house in Dallas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: This week in Covid news: Global inequities in vaccine doses; travel advice from the C.D.C.; and Cuomo’s book.
description: A new analysis by The New York Times found that although half a billion Covid-19 vaccine doses have been administered worldwide, more than 75 percent of them have been used by the world’s richest countries. Experts say that it’s not the inability of poorer countries to buy the vaccines, but how and when deals for the doses were struck.
content: A new analysis by The New York Times found that although half a billion Covid-19 vaccine doses have been administered worldwide, more than 75 percent of them have been used by the world’s richest countries. Experts say that it’s not the inability of poorer countries to buy the vaccines, but how and when deals for the doses were struck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Stanford Holds Off South Carolina to Reach Title Game
description: The Cardinal won a tense battle and advanced to the national final for the first time since 2010.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Stanford is back in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament title game for the first time since 2010 after sneaking past South Carolina on Friday night, 66-65, in a back-and-forth battle that came down to two missed shots by the Gamecocks on the final possession.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your New Favorite Weeknight Pasta
description: A not-so-secret ingredient packs Eric Kim’s new creamy pasta with umami.
content: If you’re on the hunt for a new weeknight pasta recipe, look no further than Eric Kim’s latest. His creamy asparagus pasta (above) is rich with umami, thanks to dried kelp and roasted seaweed. It’s also our most popular recipe of the week, and “the most amazing and unique thing I have made in a long time,” wrote one NYT Cooking reader. If your weeknight rotation is set, but you need a hand with Easter brunch, check out Melissa Clark’s new savory bread pudding with artichokes, Cheddar and scallions. For more inspiration, explore our collection of the 10 most sought-after recipes this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Would You Jump In to Stop an Assault?
description: A recent video showed several men seeming to ignore an anti-Asian attack in Midtown. Yet research shows that most people are more than willing to intervene and help someone.
content: Imagine that you’re walking on the street and see a man viciously beating an older woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Sameer Yasir, Julfikar Ali Manik and Raphael Minder
title: Bangladesh and parts of India look to lockdowns as a wave of cases hits South Asia, and more news around the world.
description: Some countries in the densely populated region, home to one-quarter of the world’s population, are facing “a storm” of virus infections.
content: NEW DELHI — As a new wave of coronavirus infections grips the densely populated region of South Asia, home to a quarter of the world’s population, Bangladesh on Saturday announced a second lockdown and officials in Mumbai, India’s largest city, said they were on the verge of declaring one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Game Changers
description: Angela Olson Halsted and Doug Peterson pull off a neat double play.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I like this little factoid for people who take note of our constructors’ comings and goings: Angela Olson Halsted made her Times crossword debut with Doug Peterson on a Tuesday grid nearly exactly a decade ago. They met at a crossword tournament in 2007 and have been friends ever since, bonding over puzzles and the other national pastime, which go together like chocolate and peanut butter. Opening day for baseball was April 1, so we’re right on time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Jordan’s Former Crown Prince, in Video, Reports His Detention
description: In a video obtained by The New York Times, Hamzah Bin Hussein, the former crown prince of Jordan, said he had been ordered to remain at home incommunicado because of claims that he attended meetings where the king was criticized.
content: In a video obtained by The New York Times, Hamzah Bin Hussein, the former crown prince of Jordan, said he had been ordered to remain at home incommunicado because of claims that he attended meetings where the king was criticized.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Appalling Lack of Public Toilets’ in the U.S.
description: Readers agree with Nicholas Kristof that it’s a serious issue, cite how it affects women and the disabled, and relate an anecdote about Abbie Hoffman.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 3, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 3, 2021.
content: An article on Tuesday about the expanded N.F.L. season described incorrectly what else the N.F.L. did when it expanded the regular season to 16 games from 14 in 1978. It added two wild-card teams and an additional round to the playoffs; it did not introduce wild-card teams so it could add an additional round to the playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times
